text: Even as kids we knew this music was special. Sure there were catchy tunes in other games at the time but this sounded like a CD. text: Maybe I've commented it before, but at a time I worked at video game store early/mid 2000s. We had loads of old-school games and upon boredom (and manager equally bored and cool we had the shop tidy) put whatever system and games on our test system side. We discovered Tim Follin one day and started seeking out his compositions. I remember walking in to Solstice on a repeat for a bit. Tim knows his shit.

author: BurnSchulz

text:
SNES used a soundprocessor...which means you don¬¥t have to put sound-calculations on your cpu.

The Soundchip in SNES was called the "SPC7000". It was made by Sony in these days (where Sony was still a music-genius!).

Today Sony is no longer what i call a "music-genius" and they have given up on Soundchip-production or using their own sound-chips.

Soundchips are more expensive than cpu-sounds, you have to know...

Soundchips like the SPC 7000 are capable (Nintendo-consoles to also use soundchips are Gamecube, Wii, 3DS and WiiU!) of handling highest-quality MIDI-sounds (or other sounds like MP3, AAC etc) without costing any ressources on the cpu!

text:
There are more powerful sound-chips/cards now then there were in SNES (late 1980s, early 1990s) days, dude ;)

3DS has a much faster soundprocessor allready (134 Mhz, 32 channels+!, MP3/AAC and MIDI-capable!).
gamecube, which came after the N64 had better soundprocessor as well (Well, something similar than 3DS has). And the Wii and WiiU are the latest and pretty much highend- in terms of what you can get in sound-quality today!


From Sony, only Playstation 1 and 2 used soundchips. They were similar as Gamecube¬¥s soundchip.

If you want to start, i recommend you program for 3DS dude. It has 134 Mhz, you can do a TON more than shown here in SNES-soundchip-days where you only had like 10 Mhz-soundchips with max. 8 channels...

Look up the 3DS-music and it¬¥s capabilities and start to program for it¬¥s ARM-chip if you want to handle it.

text:
Unfortunately, you're all wrong. Time signature is largely just a number which the composer uses to get his or her point across. Depending on how long the phrases are, or how they sound or feel, you can say 7/4 or 7/8 -- Depending how many beats per minute the song is also affects this.

As soon as the song starts, you can tick 7/8 phrases until the song turns into 4/4 @ 0:50 -- (or 7/4 if you feel more comfortable that way, or depending on how many measures there are and how you would like to arrange or divide them up)
author: Joseph Messano

text: @ √âmilie-Ren√©e Beaumont -- I'm sorry, but what you said doesn't always have to be true and it isn't. The song feels way better to me when I drum it thinking 7/8 during those parts, but then again my own point is moot because 7/4 and 7/8 are the same thing except a phrase of 7/4 is twice as long as a phrase of 7/8
author: Joseph Messano

text: Except the "4/4" part isn't actually 4/4 either; the last beat in each bar is only three steps long as opposed to four for the others, making it 15/16. It does briefly transition into 4/4 after that, but that's not until like 32 bars in.

text: Just in case anyone was wondering, this whole song is just based around some transposed Maj7 chords in 7/8 time. Even me (a shit guitarist) learned this fairly quickly. What makes it so rad is how the movements are. Just shows how far you can take a single chord in a song. Very brilliant work.

text: @Highway Guy¬†Nah I mean playing something with an emphasis on chromatic scale like a guitar or a piano will certainly help with your ear training (Although you probably already knew that) but music theory and ability are definitely not mutually exclusive. I happen to know only a decent amount from my experience with different settings and different instruments. I mean yes if you do wind up picking up a different instrument you WILL get a new perspective on things just due to the fact that common practices and techniques for instruments are always at least a tiny bit different but I can't say it's going to help your theory knowledge for sure. I mean then again you're talking to someone who learned music very differently than your average musician. Like I can tell you a lot of stuff about theory that some people would consider adept or even advanced practices yet I can't even read music. My girlfriend who's super by the books and was in a bunch of ensembles is always laughing at me about that lol
author: Realredraccoon

text: Well a lot of people would say so but it's all about bridging the gap between your comfort zone and outside of your comfort zone. I'd say maybe acclimate in a way where it's not something completely different so you're not totally lost. I've been in that position a bunch of times and it's super discouraging. Like I hope that helps. If you have any other questions on specifics or whatever feel free to ask!

author: Kelohmello

text:
He sure did.¬† Time Trax is what he did on Genesis and it is awesome; the man is incredible.

Point being, the Genesis chip in itself was limited by the folks who made music for it, many of which never got to know the chip properly like Follin did.¬† It's a good sound chip and underrated.

SNES and Genesis' chips did different things anyhow.¬† They used very different technologies.¬† Genesis used FM,¬† SNES used Wavetable. Wavetable takes PCM samples and plays them all back at different pitches. FM builds soundwaves from scratch using math. It was difficult, but possible, to create realistic effects, but it was more common at the time the Genesis was new. As for the SPC700 chip, that was bleeding edge and a gamble for Nintendo.

Both were suited to certain sounds; Genesis to rock, SNES to orchestral. I will say that in general, the SPC700 is better for soft strings.¬†

text: You see it depended more on the Composers then the soundchip, I can tell you easily the Ost for Vigilante 8 was better then the psx on the 64 which used a format that was far lower performing then the cd's when it came to multimedia in general (cartridges). Composers basically had to change the whole song to fit it on each of the different soundchips since they were differently abled then eachother.
author: Joe Francisco DeFreitas

text:
Definitely and I agree with Joey.¬† I do know there was a lot of confusion from companies and such on how to compose for the Genesis chip in general because of some reason that's listed someplace, but like any form of chip, there are folks who know how to work with any limitation and strengths to make it sound unique and awesome.¬† In some ways a soundchip's tech can make an impact, but a lot of it may even have to do with budget and porting.

Either way, the chip for SNES and Genesis did some different things and are like apples and oranges for a true comparison.
